Dear Ms. Canales:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
***This report contains sexually explicit information***
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000947
Special Investigation Intake Date: August 18, 2025
License #: CI370377212
Licensee Group Organization: New Hope Youth Services, LLC
Licensee Designee: Michael Cantrell
Chief Administrator: Marci CANALES
Agency Name: New Hope Youth Center
Agency Address: 1719 E HIGH ST
MT PLEASANT, MI 48858-8989
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 04/09/2027
Capacity: 15

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section Health services; policies and procedures.
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that a youth's medical needs were not
addressed while residing at the facility for the past two years. The
youth told staff that their breasts were leaking, and the staff never
sought a medical evaluation. Upon entering a new placement in
July, a youth had labs completed which had abnormal results.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 8/28/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Complainant reported
Youth A’s prolactin levels have decreased and was found to be
due to her prescribed medications. Complainant reported Youth
A’s new medical provider adjusted Youth A’s medication.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 8/18/2025. Chief Administrator reported she was not
aware of any information regarding Youth A’s medical lab levels
nor did she have any knowledge of Youth A reporting concerns of
lactating (discharge from her breast). Chief Administrator reported
Medical Technician would have more information as Medical
Technician addresses and ensures youth’s medical needs are met
while at the facility.
Assistant Facility Administrator was interviewed face-to-face
at the facility on 8/18/2025. Assistant Facility Administrator
2

reported she was aware of Youth A lactating however did not
recall specific information regarding when the concern arose.
Assistant Facility Administrator reported Youth A was taken to
medical appointments regarding this concern as Assistant Facility
Administrator reported she took Youth A for an ultrasound of her
breast. Assistant Facility Administrator reported she did not recall
the medical findings of the ultrasound however she recalled there
was no concerns with breast cancer as this was a concern of
Youth A’s.
Medical Technician was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 8/18/2025 and 8/21/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker 1. Medical Technician reported she was aware of Youth A
having a high prolactin level as this is common in youth prescribed
Zyprexa and this was being monitored by Youth A’s Psychatrist
and Primary Care Physician. Medical Technician reported Youth
A was “heavy chested” and Youth A reported concerns to her
regarding “leaking from her breasts” which is a side effect of
Zyprexa. Medical Technician reported Youth A was seen
regarding this concern by her Primary Care Physician and
Psychatrist. Medical Technician reported Youth A had a breast
exam and an ultrasound on her breasts while at the facility due to
the concerns of “nipple discharge”. Medical Technician reported
Youth A’s former caseworker, Foster Care Worker, was made
aware of all these concerns. Medical Technician reported Youth A
was prescribed Zyprexa prior to being placed at the facility and
was switched to Risperidone due to the concerns however
Risperidone also has a known side effect of causing “nipple
discharge”. Medical Technician reported Youth A informed her in
fall of 2024 she was no longer having “nipple discharge”. Medical
Technician reported Youth A also had high levels of triglycerides
as Youth A was diagnosed as being overweight and this was
being addressed. Medical Technician reported the high level of
triglycerides was due to Youth A’s eating habits and Youth A was
receiving treatment through Helen DeVos to address weight
management. Medical Technician reported Youth A had a fear of
needles and often would refuse having her blood work taken for
labs as well as immunizations.
MDHHS Worker 2 was interviewed via telephone on 8/19/2025.
MDHHS Worker 2 was assigned as a courtesy worker to interview
Youth A. MDHHS Worker 2 reported Youth A was interviewed at
her foster care placement and did not disclose much about her
medical needs while at the facility. MDHHS Worker 2 reported
Youth A reported she was on medication however did not know
the names of the medication. Youth A reported she did not want
3

to talk about any of the side effects she had on her medications
while she was placed at the facility other than she told Medical
Technician and nothing was done about it.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/21/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Youth B
reported attending medical appointments while at the facility.
Youth B reported Medical Technician monitors youth’s medical
concerns. Youth B reported if a youth has a medical concern at
the facility the process is to complete a medical slip and place it in
the locked drop box outside the medical office. Youth B reported
the medical slip box is not checked often. Youth B reported she
has lab work completed at the facility approximately every six
months and is informed of the results. Youth B reported she is
scheduled for surgery this month to address a medical condition
with her nose. Youth B reported she has monthly virtual
appointments with the facilities Psychiatrist.
Youth C was interviewed via telephone on 8/22/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Youth C reported Medical
Technician takes youth’s health concerns seriously and addresses
concerns. Youth C reported she feels comfortable discussing
medical concerns with Medical Technician.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on 8/22/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 3. Youth D reported all of her
medical needs were met at the facility while she was placed there.
Youth D reported no knowledge of any youth’s medical needs not
being addressed.
Youth E was interviewed via telephone on 8/22/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Youth E reported she
addresses medical concerns with Medical Technician at the
facility. Youth E reported Medical Technician takes all medical
concerns seriously and makes follow-up appointments when
needed. Youth E reported some youth do refuse to attend
medical appointments at the facility, however did not state specific
youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 8/22/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Staff 1 reported no
concerns about the facility not taking medical concerns seriously
and no knowledge of any youth’s medical needs not being
addressed. Staff 1 reported she did not have any specific
knowledge of Youth A’s medical concerns. Staff 1 reported no
4

youth have ever reported any concerns to her regarding medical
slips not being tended to.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 8/22/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Staff 2 reported no
concerns with youth not receiving medical treatment while at the
facility. Staff 2 reported several youth have refused to attend
medical appointments while at the facility including Youth A who
refused multiple times to go to appointments or follow guidelines
such as fasting prior to appointments. Staff 2 reported Medical
Technician takes all medical concerns seriously at the facility.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conference on
8/25/2025. Foster Care Worker reported she was Youth A’s
worker for approximately two years while Youth A was placed at
the facility. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A disclosed to her
during a visit she was having discharge from her nipples and
Foster Care Worker followed up with Medical Technician
regarding the concern. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A was
taken in for a medical appointment regarding the concern as she
believed it was determined the nipple discharge was associated
with Youth A being on birth control. Foster Care Worker reported
she did not recall Youth A making any other comments or
concerns about nipple discharge. Foster Care Worker reported
the concern was being addressed with Youth A’s Psychiatrist and
Primary Care Physician through the facility. Foster Care Worker
reported Youth A did have an ultrasound completed on her breast
and believed the results were normal however could not recall the
specifics as Foster Care Worker reported Youth A had several
medical issues being addressed by the facility including x-rays for
her back due to a sledding incident as well as the facility
addressing concerns of Youth A being overweight and working
with a nutritionist to address the concerns. Foster Care Worker
reported Medical Technician did well keeping her up to date and
providing medical documentation. Foster Care Worker reported
she did not recall receiving lab work ups on Youth A. Foster Care
Worker reported Youth A “was very stubborn” and refused to
attend medical appointments at times. Foster Care Worker
reported Youth A was supposed to be watching what foods she
was eating and working out, however Youth A would demand junk
food and would throw tantrums if she did not get what she wanted.
Foster Care Worker reported the facility was doing the best to
their ability to meet Youth A’s medical needs and Medical
Technician was addressing concerns and stayed in
communication with Foster Care Worker.
5

Psychiatrist was interviewed via telephone on 8/28/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Psychiatrist reported she
did not have Youth A's medical records readily available.
Psychiatrist reported usually if a youth has high lab levels, she
collaborates with the youth’s primary care physician. Psychiatrist
reported several of the medications Youth A was prescribed could
have caused several side effects, but was unable to specifically
say what medication may have caused exactly what side effects.
The high prolactin and high cholesterol levels are not uncommon
for metabolic medications. Psychiatrist reported metformin is
commonly prescribed to help with weight loss and can cause high
liver enzymes. Psychiatrist reported Youth A’s lab results were
common with a youth on medications however indicated that lab
results can also be elevated based on familial history as well as
youth are growing which is why lab work is completed and
monitored to be able to compare levels. Psychiatrist reported she
could not recall specifically talking to Youth A regarding nipple
discharge. Psychiatrist reported medications like Risperdal have
side effects which include breast leakage. Psychiatrist reported the
facility is good at keeping up with appointments and youth medical
needs are met. Psychiatrist reported another side effect from the
medications Youth A was prescribed could be weight gain.
Psychiatrist reported it depends on the level if a youth should be
on a lipid lowering medication. There may be non-pharmacological
methods that could be utilized, also, such as changing dietary
habits. Psychiatrist reported Youth A's doctors were trying to
change her diet to combat some of her weight management
needs.
Primary Care Physician (PCP) was interviewed via telephone
on 8/28/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. PCP
reported Youth A had an appointment with her on 6/18/25 and this
was the only appointment she had with Youth A. PCP reported
Youth A was previously attending appointments with Nurse
Practitioner (NP) who left the practice in the spring 2025. PCP
reviewed Youth A's medical history and labs which showed high
cholesterol levels, so NP discussed Youth A making lifestyle
changes regarding diet and exercise. PCP reported Youth A was
seen by her on 6/18/2025 for asthma concerns. PCP reported
they didn't discuss all of Youth A's medical needs due to Youth A
already having a well-child appointment scheduled for August
2025. At the June appointment, Youth A's blood pressure was
slightly elevated which PCP attributed to Youth A being
overweight for her age. PCP reported they discussed diet and
6

lifestyle changes and discussed continuing her inhaler. PCP
reported at the appointment, PCP started Youth A on Metformin
for weight management, to see if this might curb her appetite.
Metformin usually doesn't affect the liver. Rather, it usually affects
the kidney. PCP reported being overweight could cause high liver
enzymes. PCP reported from reviewing Youth A’s medical
records, the facility was addressing Youth A's needs and ensuring
that Youth A was attending appointments and following medical
recommendations. PCP reported Youth A’s lab results were not
abnormal based off what medications she was prescribed as well
as being overweight. PCP reported the elevated prolactin would
not have necessarily been caused by these factors, and she
would have done further investigating into why. PCP reported with
high prolactin and the nipple discharge; other labs can be ordered.
PCP reported Youth A was on Risperidone, which can cause high
prolactin levels.
Nurse Practitioner (NP) was interview via telephone on
8/28/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. NP reported
she was Youth A’s primary care provider from fall 2024 until
March 2025. NP reported she left the medical facility resulting in
her no longer providing care for Youth A and she no longer had
access to Youth A's medical records. NP reported she was
treating Youth A for back pain and being overweight which she
attributed the back pain to Youth A being overweight as well as
being large chested. NP reported while she was treating Youth A,
Youth A was experiencing breast leakage which NP ordered an
ultrasound and lab work to investigate the issue. NP reported she
ordered labs be completed as there are different reasons that
someone can experience leaking/discharge from the breast
including high levels of prolactin, a side effect from medication, a
result of being overweight, as well as a medical issue. NP
reported the lab results showed Youth A had high prolactin levels.
NP reported normally youth are not put on medications to address
high cholesterol levels and typically this issue is first attempted to
be addressed with weight management through diet and exercise
which was why Youth A was referred to Helen DeVos for weight
management. NP reported there can be a few reasons for why the
lab results were elevated such as diet being the largest contributor
followed by familial history, and then by medications prescribed.
NP reported the lab results were being addressed by ruling out the
basics first such as diet. NP reported the facility was routinely
bringing Youth A for appointments and typically Medical
7

Technician was the individual bringing Youth A. NP reported the
facility was addressing Youth A’s medical needs.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on 8/21/2025. The locked medical
slip box was observed outside the medical office. Medical
Technician opened the medical slip box which a few medical slips
inside. Upon reviewing the medical slips that were in the medical
box, all the slips were blank and had no concerns documented.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Health Care
Services Policy: All youth admitted shall have on file a
current physical examination. If the youth had not had a
physical examination within the previous twelve months,
one will be completed within the first 30 days of placement.
Youth with medical, mental health needs, or complaints are
to be seen in a timely fashion. When a youth presents or is
found to have a non-urgent condition (new diagnosis) or a
non-emergent/urgent pre-existing injury they shall be
scheduled for the next facility designated health authority
medical visit. The designated health authority will determine
if any appointment/referral will need to be made while the
youth is at the facility or can wait until the youth is released.
When the need for referral is documented the facility
medical staff will contact the appropriate outside
provider/specialist to set an appointment.
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Sick Call
Process, Requests, and Complaints Policy: All youth at the
facility shall be able to make sick call requests and have
their complaints treated appropriately through the sick call
system. Sick call care shall be available to all youth two
times a day, seven days per week. Sick call care shall be
provided by licensed health care professionals within the
scope of practice. Youth shall access sick call by
completing the sick call request form. Completed sick call
forms shall be placed by the youth in the programs
confidential and secure sick call box to then be provided to
the nurse.
• My Michigan Health University of Michigan Ultrasound
report dated 9/10/2024 for Youth A: Ultrasound breast
8

diagnostic targeted bilateral was negative and no follow up
treatment was needed. Ultrasound was completed due to
bilateral clearish nipple discharge occurring twice a month.
No sonographic abnormalities bilateral breast. Recommend
continued clinical management, follow up sonographic
evaluation if persistent nipple discharge.
• Youth Opportunity Evart Academy Medication Review
Session for Youth A dated 10/27/2023: Youth A is on two
atypical antipsychotic medication, and it was discussed to
wean off Zyprexa and only continue with Abilify. Consent
was obtained to DC Zyprexa in approximately two weeks
and continue with other medications. Lab results showed
MCV 76.3 (low), MCH 24.6 (low), RDW 15.3 (high), LDL-
Cholesterol 135 (high), Triglycerides 187 (high), LIPID
Panel Cholesterol 230 (high), NON-HDL Cholesterol 167
(high), Thyroid Panel T3 Uptake 18 (low). Youth A is
responding well to medications as well as controlled in
structured environment.
• Lab work for Youth A dated 8/5/2023 and 12/19/24
• Psychotropic Medication Informed Consent for Youth A
dated 5/29/2025 listed Youth A being recommended the
following medication: Risperidone, Cymbalta, Melatonin,
Prazosin, Metformin, and Topamax. Psychotropic
Medication Form was signed by Foster Care Worker
5/30/2025 and Youth A on 6/4/2025.
• Isabella Citizens for Health Patient Plan for Youth A dated
6/18/2025: Youth A was seen for Asthma. Assessment:
Overweight in childhood with body mass index greater than
85th percentile. Patient Plan: Dietary counseling- limit/avoid
high calorie/fatty foods. Fast foods, and sugary drinks.
Goals of 5 servings fruits and vegetable per day. Discussed
CA/Vitamin D and Iron demands for age as well as age
appropriate foods. Exercise Counseling: Goal of physical
activity or active play everyday and discussed minimizing
screen time and amount of screen time appropriate for age.
• Email from Medical Technician to Foster Care Worker
dated 8/20/2024: Youth A had her yearly well-child exam
completed, and x-ray results reviewed showing no
abnormalities. Several concerns were addressed including
nipple discharge, back, and neck pain. Youth A expressed
9

a desire to stop her birth control due to concerns about
weight gain. The provider agreed to discontinue the birth
control which may help reduce the nipple discharge. A
breast exam was performed, and an ultrasound will be
ordered to further evaluate a few lumps that were detected.
A referral will be made for physical therapy to help alleviate
her back and neck pain. Youth A is scheduled for a follow
up with the provider on 11/22/2024. A walk in appointment
will also be arranged to catch up on vaccines and lab work.
• Email from Medical Technician to Foster Care Worker
dated 11/25/2024: Youth A had a medication review on
11/22/2024 where Zoloft was reviewed along with her
recent behaviors. It was suggested to taper her off Zoloft
and transition to Cymbalta as well as add the Risperidone
as a PRN. Youth A had a primary care appointment and
reported no longer experiencing nipple discharge. A
referral will be sent to Helen DeVos for weight management
support. Youth A’s next primary care appointment is
scheduled for 2/27/2024.
• Email from Medical Technician to Fosster Care Worker
dated 12/12/2024: Medical Technician provided Youth A’s
weight management appointment. The provider suggested
starting a medication and will reach out to the psychiatrist
to discuss the medication. Lab work was ordered, however
Youth A refused to have completed while at Helen DeVos
as well as this morning. Youth A has set goals to work out
two to three times a week as well as make healthier food
choices. Youth A has a follow up appointment scheduled
for 2/5/2025.
• Email from Foster Care Worker dated 8/19/2025: Youth A
has a long history of defiance and refusal to take
medications or follow what doctors stated, or even getting
her update on immunizations. When the initial concern of
nipple discharge was made, Youth A was taken to ensure
she was not pregnant as she had been sexually assaulted
prior to going to the facility while AWOL. Due to Youth A’s
prior interactions with boys, Youth A was placed on birth
control by a former worker. Youth A was asked after she
disclosed the nipple discharge if there had been any
10

changes and Youth A never mentioned it was continuing to
occur.
• Email from Medical Technician to Consultant dated
8/20/2025: Youth A refused to have lab work completed on
3/20/2024, 6/18/2024, 7/22/2024, 12/11/2024, 12/12/2024
as well as additional dates. Medical Technician provided
documentation of contacts to verify.
• Medical Technician’s personnel file: Medical Technician
has no discipline in her personnel file and was last trained
on medical treatment 2/27/2025.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. Per interviews and review of
documentation, Youth A’s medical needs were being addressed
while placed at the facility. The facility was aware of Youth A
reporting leaking discharge from her breast and worked to
address this with PCP who ordered an ultrasound and lab work.
The facility was ensuring Youth A attended appointments as well
as follow-up on referrals. The facility communicated with previous
foster care worker regarding status of appointments per
documentation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
9/29/2025

Licensing Consultant
